title: China Railways KD1
text:
The China Railways KD1 class locomotives were a class of <a href="2-8-0">2-8-0</a> <a href="steam%20locomotive">steam locomotive</a>s operated by <a href="China%20Railway">China Railway</a>, originally built for the <a href="South%20Manchuria%20Railway">South Manchuria Railway</a> ("Mantetsu") and the <a href="Manchukuo%20National%20Railway">Manchukuo National Railway</a> by <a href="American%20Locomotive%20Company">ALCo</a> of the <a href="United%20States%20of%20America">United States</a> in 1907 and 1908. The "Sori" name comes from the <a href="Whyte%20notation">American naming system</a> for steam locomotives, in which the 2-8-0 <a href="wheel%20arrangement">wheel arrangement</a> is called "Consolidation".
History.
After ordering two 2-8-0 tender locomotives from ALCO in 1906 which became the <a href="China%20Railways%20KD23">class H</a>, Mantetsu returned to ALCO again for more, receiving five new engines in 1907 from ALCO's Cooke works in <a href="New%20Jersey">New Jersey</a>. Initially numbered 3 through 7, these became class H1 in the new <a href="Rolling%20stock%20of%20the%20South%20Manchuria%20Railway%23Classification%20systems">classification system</a> introduced that year, under which system they were renumbered 1002 through 1006, and through the end of 1908 a total of 46 were delivered, numbered 1002–1032 and 1053–1067; they were soon renumbered 1002 through 1047. Initially used only on the mainline, from 1912 they were also used on the <a href="Shendan%20Railway">Anfeng Line</a> on both goods trains and mixed trains. In 1920, another change to Mantetsu's classification system led to the H1 class becoming the Sorii class (ソリイ), whilst retaining their previous numbers. Between 1923 and 1925 they were rebuilt with <a href="superheater">superheater</a>s, and between 1927 and 1931, seventeen were transferred to the <a href="Fushun%20Mining%20Group">Fushun Coal Mine</a>. In 1931, seven were loaned to the <a href="Sitao%20Railway">Sitao Railway</a>, and during the time of the <a href="Mukden%20Incident">Mukden Incident</a>, some were used to pull military trains and armoured trains. In 1933, number 1002 was transferred to the <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Army">army</a> to be used to build a prototype for an armoured train. Between 1933 and 1936, fifteen were transferred to the <a href="Manchukuo%20National%20Railway">Manchukuo National Railway</a> where they were designated Sorina class (ソリナ), and between 1934 and 1936, Mantetsu assigned some to work on the <a href="Hambuk%20Line%23History">North Chosen Line</a>. With the introduction of the final new classification scheme, the Mantetsu Sorii and Manchukuo National Sorina classes were unified as the Sorii class, with the Mantetsu engines numbered 1–9, and the Manchukuo National units becoming numbers 501–515. In 1942, the engines that had been transferred to the Fushun mines were returned to Mantetsu, becoming numbers 10 through 26.
Postwar.
After the end of the <a href="Pacific%20War">Pacific War</a>, 23 Sorii class locomotives remained on the rosters of Mantetsu and Manchukuo National, with the other 18 thought to have been scrapped or transferred to other railways, including the <a href="North%20China%20Transportation%20Company">North China Transportation Company</a>. Of the 23, five were assigned to each of the <a href="Jinzhou">Jinzhou</a> and <a href="Qiqihar">Qiqihar</a> Railway Bureaux, four to the <a href="Mudanjiang">Mudanjiang</a> bureau and one to the <a href="Harbin">Harbin</a> bureau, three were on loan to the Construction Office, three were on loan to other railways, with the disposition of the remaining two being unclear; these 23 were taken over by the Republic of China Railway. After the establishment of the <a href="People%27s%20Republic%20of%20China">People's Republic of China</a>, these locomotives were designated class MK1.
